title: What's News: World-Wide — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 23, 2019).

A top U.S. diplomat in Kyiv said in prepared testimony that Trump made nearly $400 million in aid contingent on Ukraine's president investigating Biden and alleged Ukrainian interference in the 2016 U.S. election.

U.K. lawmakers endorsed Johnson's Brexit agreement, an important step that gave it critical momentum, but not a decisive one, as they subsequently rejected the prime minister's plan to rush the deal through Parliament.

Russia agreed to help Turkey drive out Kurdish militias from a "safe zone" in northeastern Syria, highlighting the rebalance of power in war-torn Syria as U.S. troops leave.

Iraq's government fired scores of senior military commanders for their role in a deadly crackdown on protesters, aiming to avert a potential explosion of unrest.

Premiums for the most popular health plans sold under the ACA will drop for the second straight year, the administration said.

Brazilian senators overwhelmingly approved on Tuesday a sweeping revamp of the country's insolvent social-security system.

Eleven parents who prosecutors say were involved in the college-admissions cheating scheme are now facing additional charges.

U.S. traffic fatalities fell for a second consecutive year in 2018, posting a 2.4% decline, but deaths of pedestrians rose 3.4%.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 23, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
